scenes.location: FIRST TEXAS BANK ARCHER CITY CONT.
characters: OH, MAN ROBBING BANKS IS HARD WORK,
FOR YOU KNOW WYOMING WILL BE YOUR
LONG AGO AND FAR AWAY. IN MY OLD
THE WORLD ALL WHICH A WAY, JUST
MISFORTUNE AND NONE OF MY OWN,
AS I WALKED OUT ONE BRIGHT SUNNY
YIPPEE HIYIYO, GET A LONG YOU
LET THE WORLD CALL ME A FOOL, BUT
YIPPEE HIYIYO GET ALONG, GET ALONG,
LOPIN' ALONG, HIS HAPPY SHELL BACK,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SILHOUETTES. MEN. Hard to say who for two reasons: th morning sun through the glass door and the ski masks pull over their faces.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: What in the devil --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER
dialogues.text: (Offering her a hand) Stand up and take us to the cash drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not. The robber kneels below the glare and points a revolver a her face.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER 2
dialogues.text: We ain’t askin’. She scrambles to her feet and is escorted behind the coun

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: There’s no money in the drawers yet. It’s in the safe and I ain’t got the key.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER
dialogues.text: Prove it. She opens the drawers. Sure enough, they’re empty.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Y'all are new at this I’m guessing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER 2
dialogues.text: Where’s the money?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I told you, in the safe.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER 2
dialogues.text: Who’s got the key?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Mister Clauson. He’1ll be here soon, and I suggest you fellers don’t be. All you're guilty of right now is being stupid. Just leave and that’s all it’ll be. One of the robbers spins her to face him. Grabs her by th throat. His cold eyes stare deep into hers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER 2
dialogues.text: Call me stupid again.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Think you scare me? You stupid son of a bitch. Uh oh.  3. The thief’s partner steps up, puts a hand on the angry ma shoulder, easing him back, and steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER
dialogues.text: When does Mister Clauson get here?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Eight-thirty every morning. They look to the clock on the wall -- 8:29. The other robber grabs her by the arm and drags her aroun the main foyer of the little bank. Points his pistol at h head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER 2
dialogues.text: Sit. She starts to move toward a small sofa.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBER 2, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where the hell are you going? Sit on the floor. She does. Right in the middle of the bank. She looks up a them -- scared for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ‘78 Buick in mint condition comes to a stop in front of bank. MR. CLAUSON, 50's, bit of a belly and barely any ha climbs out and looks up at the bank sign, digitally displaying the time and temperature. The time is 8:30am. The temperature is 98.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Goodness, it’s gonna be a cooker. He moves toward the entrance of the bank. Behind him we s virtually no signs of life. It’s a miracle this bank is e open. INT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- CONT. Mr. Clauson steps through and sees:  Elsie sitting uncomfortably in the center of the lobby, propping all her weight on one arm, like a broken chair.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Elsie, you alright? She shakes her head ‘no’ as a pistol is placed to Mr. Clauson’s temple ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burnt field, charred and smoking, whizzes by as the eng whines. We see two men: TOBY HANSON, late 30's, a kind face marked by years of su and disappointment, rides shotgun. It’s not the face of a thief, it is the face of a farmer. Behind the wheel is TANNER HANSON, 40, his brother’s oppo in every way: mustache, shaggy hair, an air of danger tha attracts as many women as it repels. He lights a smoke as Toby wipes sweat from his brow. Tanner grins from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Just like the army. Doin’ more before nine a.m. than most folks do all goddam day. Toby looks straight ahead. They ride in silence for a mom Then Tanner explodes --

dialogues.speaker: WHOOOOOOOOOHOOCOOOHOOHOO
dialogues.text: He pounds the dash. Toby waits for the storm to pass. It does. Silence again.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You need to go a little easier on the tellers.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I go as easy on them as they go on me. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down. He doesn’t. In the distance, they see the throbbing lights of a SHERI CRUISER headed toward them.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Slow down --

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I ain’t speeding. The cruiser races toward them. Tanner drives without a ca in the world. Toby is frozen to his seat, eyes tracking t car as it approaches. The cruiser whips by. Toby looks in the side mirror, cert the vehicle is going to turn around. It doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, little brother? We ain’t got a worry in the world. Tanner takes a long pull from his cigarette, and looks ou over the black top.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Plannin’ this and doin’ it’s two different things. Tanner laughs. His demeanor is so relaxed, you'd think th were taking a drive with no destination at all.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Shit, most people that do this don’t think to plan at all. ... You know, we're half way to Olney. Might as well put ourselves a day ahead. Toby looks exhausted. But it’s true. Tanner looks at him smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon. Early bird gets the worm. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Slow down.  He doesn’t. EXT. TWO LANE HIGHWAY -- CONT. The Camaro pulls away from us. We try to keep up, but it disappears over a rise. We stare at broken yellow lines a they race underneath us. CAMERA RISES. We see the Camaro in the distance. It is th only car on the road. In fact, it is the only sign of lif any direction. Smoke rises from scorched fields in every direction. From our vantage point, it seems the whole wor is on fire ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This branch was built in the fifties and hasn’t had a rem since. There is one surveillance camera mounted above the teller’s counter. A MAN IN HIS 80'S is placing rolls of coins on the counte before a chubby, young TELLER. There is a dolly loaded wi three cardboard boxes beside him. They are the only two people in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I found three boxes in the barn. Lord knows how long they been sittin there. (The old man chuckles) I been living on an inmate’s diet and had all these boxes just sitting under feed sacks. The teller smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: How do you forget such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Old as I am, lucky I could find my way here. The teller examines a roll of pennies.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: This one says 1953. She breaks open the roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if any of these is collector’s items. You could be sitting on a fortune here. We hear a JINGLE OF BELLS from the front door. In a flash pistol is pointed at the old man and a blurred image leap over the counter. TANNER, in ski mask, is now behind the teller, pistol to head. Toby appears beside the old man.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Open the drawer. Her eyes go wide. She raises her hands to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put yer hands down and open the drawer. She does.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Ones, fives, tens, and twenties. No hundreds.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Don’t this figure. Good lord won't even let me have it for a damn day.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (Looking over the boxes) We don’t want your coins, old man.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: So you boys is robbing the bank?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Keep your hands on the counter. The old man simply can’t wrap his head around what he’s seeing.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: That's crazy ... Ya’ll ain’t even Mexican. She reaches for the ink pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no. Leave that where it is. And none of them in bundles, just the loose cash.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You oughta be ashamed of yerself --

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Oh, I am. Make no mistake. But I’m doing it anyway. Put your hands on the counter where I can see em, old man. Got a pistol on you?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Damn right I do.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: (Looks hard at Toby)Keep up with the circumstances, okay? Toby shakes his head at the scolding and frisks him, finds a snub nose .38 and sets it on the counter, out of the old man’s reach.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You gonna steal my gun?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: (Pointing his pistol)I got my own gun --

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We ain’t stealing from you, we’re stealing from the bank.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: It’s the same thing, son. Tanner jumps the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Like hell it is. They turn and run. The old man grabs shattering glass beside them as they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers run around the building and the waiting Camaro. They tear off through the alley. his pistol and fires, exit the building. -- CONT. to the back of the bank The old man struggles out the front door, pistol in hand looks down the street. Nothing. Looks the other way. Noth there either. Just like the last town, it appears in every way to be deserted. INT. CAMARO -- RESIDENTIAL STREET -- OLNY, TEXAS -- DAY. Masks removed, the brothers are drenched in sweat. They p house after house with dead lawns and no cars in the driveway. Some of the windows are broken, some boarded up. One thin certain, whoever lived in these little towns doesn’t live here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Put the gun on the counter?? You liked to get us killed!

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m not stealing from some old man. We stealing from one place. That’s it. But Tanner isn’t angry, he’s laughing.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You're turning out to be a poor criminal. Toby opens the trash bag, judging the take. This was a mu bigger haul.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See what the early bird gets? Through the windshield we see field after field of cotton drab and stunted from the heat. Olney is far behind us no A tinge of relief on Toby’s face -- this may actually wor He leans his head back.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (The gleam returns to Tanner’s eyes) Wanna head over to the branch in Jayton? Relief gone.  10.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: NO. (He looks at his brother) We hit these banks first thing in the morning. When they’re empty... That’s the last time I care to be shot at. Toby runs his hand over his sweat-drenched face.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gotta be smart. We’re a ways from being finished.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hell, we could do this all week.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We’re gonna. Tanner laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Can’t nobody stop us ... We like the Comanches, little brother. Lords of the plains... Raiding where we please, with the whole of Texas huntin’ our shadow. Field after empty field fly by Toby’s window. He stares o over them. Tanner lights a smoke, draws in a deep drag.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lords of the plains. That’s us ... Toby looks in the direction of his greatest worry, who exhales smoke and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. TEXAS RANGER’S OFFICE -- ABILENE, TEXAS -- DAY. MARCUS HAMILTON, two weeks shy of 70, thick silver mustac sits at his desk. A large Texas flag tacked to the wall behind him. He looks over a LETTER from the DPS HEADQUARTERS in Austi The heading says it all: Mandatory Retirement Referendum. The letter is worn at the edges -- Marcus has spent a fai amount of time looking it over.  11. Marcus packs a can of Copenhagen with fifty year’s worth skill, and sticks a pinch inside his lip. A younger Ranger, and by younger I mean 50, walks in. His name is ALBERTO PARKER, and aside from his olive skin, he looks almost identical to Marcus: thick mustache, beer be gold star on a starched white shirt, bone colored Stetson hat.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You hear about these bank robberies?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Why you always dress like me? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: This is our uniform.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: We ain’t got no uniform. You can wear any color shirt you choose. You just keep choosing mine.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Texas Ranger regs say white, blue, or tan dress shirt. Stands to reason every so often we gonna end up dressed the same.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Well, they say imitation is the greatest form of flattery, Alberto. Did you know that? Alberto is half Comanche and half Latino, though his Texa twang is as pronounced as any cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Wanna hear about these bank robberies or just sit there and let Alzheimer’s run its course?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Where at?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: First Texas in Archer City and First Texas in Olney.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: FBI looking for an assist?  12.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Ain’t theirs. First Texas ain’t got branches outside the state. Not interstate commerce. A flicker of fire ignites in Marcus’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may get to have some fun before they send you to the rocking chair yet. Marcus’s chair squeaks as he leans back.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: +. I may have one hunt left in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Camaro throws dust along the dirt road as it drives p a rotting house, various outbuildings, and a collapsing b A few skinny cattle try to eek out a meal from the dead grass. The Camaro drives past the barn, past a dried pond, and stops. Toby steps out of the Camaro. Climbs on a FRONT-END LOADE bulldozer in layman’s terms). Tanner drives the Camaro in ten-foot deep ditch. Beside the ditch are THIRTY PEACH TREES, their roots protected by burlap sacks. The bulldozer roars to life and begins pushing a large pi of red dirt. INT. BULLDOZER -- CONT. We look down on the blade holding two tons of dirt. Watch it releases the load, pounding the roof of the Camaro. We see Tanner carrying two duffels and the trash bags of money toward the sheet metal barn. Half-starved cattle watch with curiosity from the relativ shade of a mesquite tree.  13. EXT. SHEET METAL BARN -- CONT. Tanner pulls open the doors to the barn. Inside, we see T VEHICLES. A Chevy Blazer, an old Ford Taurus, and a ruste Ford pick up. Tanner tosses the duffels on the hood of the Taurus. Walk out of the barn carrying the bags of money. EXT. FRONT PORCH -- HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- A LITTLE LATER. Tanner sits, guzzling a beer, an unopened Bud in his lap. Toby walks up, Tanner tosses the beer to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I need you sober.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Who the hell gets drunk off beer?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You count it? Tanner smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Ain’t my money. Toby begins stacking and counting the cash as he sips his beer.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We oughta go hit the branch in Coleman before we change this money.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We change the money first. Hit the branch in Coleman in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: It don’t make no sense to drive to Oklahoma, then drive all the way back to Coleman, then all the way back to Oklahoma when we could change all the money tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It don’t make sense to you.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That’s what I said.  14. But Toby offers no explanation.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddam that was fun ... Wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: No. Tanner laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You lying bastard. I saw you. You liked it ... looked like you were sproutin’ a little wood fer that teller in Olney too. That’s the problem with these baggy jeans -- can’t hide a hard hog against yer leg. Remind me to wear my wranglers if we start robbin’ high schools. Toby looks up.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: This ain’t supposed to be fun. And we ain’t robbing anybody. We’re robbing ‘em back. Tanner drains his beer, cracks open another.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Call it what you want. It’s the most fun I’ve had with clothes on. I wouldn’t have missed this fer the world and two hookers. Toby looks at the stacks of money.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Half way there. Tanner holds out a beer. Toby looks into his smiling eyes Shakes his head and takes it anyway. Tanner walks to the edge of the porch. Jumps off. Walks o and turns back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Boy this place looks like shit. Tanner looks over the emaciated cattle in the field besid him.  15.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ain't a decent steak between the whole lot of those sorry sons of bitches. Toby watches his brother, senses the storm brewing. Knows silence is the best weapon against it. Tanner shakes his head at the crumbling house. For the fi time, he isn’t smiling. He jumps back on the porch and wa inside. Toby rubs his sunburned temples, sighs, then stands and follows. INT. HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- CONT. Toby comes through the front door. The furniture is at le thirty years old. Boxes are stacked everywhere. We see a SUIT laying across a chair at the dining room ta On the table is a PAMPHLET from a funeral -- black and wh photo of an old woman on the front. The color version of that photo hangs on the wall. Beside the pamphlet is a FIRST TAXES BANK folder with numerous loan papers sprawled around it. Tanner steps out from the kitchen. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You haven't done much cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Cleaned mama six times a day. That was enough for me. Tanner picks up the funeral pamphlet.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: She died in the bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tanner takes off down the hall. After a moment, Toby foll  16. INT. BEDROOM -- CONT. A HOSPICE BED, complete with rails, sits in the center of room, An IV stand by its side. The sheets and blankets ar crumpled and tossed back, as if someone just climbed out.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Better get this out of here before your boys move in.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It’s on the list. Tanner sips his beer. Looks around the room. Stacks of magazines. Countless prescription bottles on the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: She was in this bed a while, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Three months. Tanner nods. Shuffles his feet. Guilt setting in.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I could've lent a hand if she'd asked. Could’ve fed them skinny cows at least.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Got nothing to feed ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Well, could’ve cleaned up this house a bit. Toby almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Never thought of you as the go-to guy for house cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: No ... Just robbing banks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Hey bud, your phone dials out, you could have checked on us anytime.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: She could’ve asked.  17. Tanner finishes his beer, crushes the can, and tosses it the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck her. She never wanted nothing to do with me anyway. Tanner walks out of the room, brushing past Toby. Toby looks at the beer can. He walks over, picks it up, a puts it on the night stand. EXT. RANCH HOUSE -- MOMENT LATER. Toby steps onto the porch. Finds Tanner leaning against a old corral fence. Toby gives his brother some distance.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: She leave a will? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Was I in it? Silence. Tanner turns to his brother, who looks down at h boots, then dead into Tanner’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: No. Tanner has to smile. Drinks from yet another beer. Toby s off the porch and walks up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The will don’t matter. She left everything to me, and by Friday, it all goes to my boys ... She didn’t mean nuthin’ by it. Mama’s been gone for years. I just tended to the body.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: She damn sure meant it. Mama was like a dog that got kicked every time it was fed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After a while she started to think the beatin’ was part of the meal. Hated me fer knowin’ the difference.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That’s not it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It’s cuz you never understood that fighting back just makes the beating last longer. Tanner laughs. So does Toby. A little.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Oh, I understood it. Tanner leans into Toby, resting his hand on his brother's neck.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's why I stopped fighting and shot that son of a bitch. They both lean on the fence, looking out over the parched field filled with mesquites -- the only plant mean enough survive in this place.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -—- ARCHER CITY, TX -- DAY. Marcus and PARKER pull up to as large a crowd as Archer C can muster: a dozen people and another dozen Sheriff's deputies stand under the awning of the bank, hiding from sun like bats. They walk toward the ‘crowd’ as a truck pulling a horse trailer slows. The window rolls down and we see a RANCHER 50, his face as weathered as it is unforgiving.

dialogues.speaker: RANCHER
dialogues.text: What’s gong on?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Somebody robbed the bank this morning.  19.

dialogues.speaker: RANCHER
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Ain’t seen no one unusual in town, have you?

dialogues.speaker: RANCHER
dialogues.text: I don’t come to town except to buy diesel and put my paycheck in that sombitch right there ( points at the bank), and you say someone robbed it?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Looks that way. The rancher shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RANCHER
dialogues.text: There was a time you could have left that bank unlocked overnight and no one steal a penny. Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I remember it. (Hands him a card) You see anyone that looks a little sideways, you give me a call.

dialogues.speaker: RANCHER
dialogues.text: Sideways don’t want to meet me. Find itself on the wrong end of a short rope.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Well, that would simplify things for everyone but you.

dialogues.speaker: RANCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe. If you can find the tree. The rancher pulls away. Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: God, I love West Texas. They walk to the bank as a DEPUTY approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Weren’t much of a robbery. Got off with just under seven thousand. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Took the drawer money. Twenty’s and under. Only loose bills.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: So no ink pack.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Nope. Marcus nods.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Smart.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That was smart, wasn’t it. Can we get a look at the video? The deputy’s eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Let me introduce you to the bank manager. Waves them over to a boiling Mr. Clauson.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Why can’t we wait inside? It’s gotta be -- He looks above them to the First Texas sign and thermomet MR. CLAUSON (CONT’D) My goodness gracious, it’s a hundred and five and barely noon.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: It’s a crime scene, Mr. Clauson.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Can we get a look at the surveillance video? Mr. Clauson shrinks a little.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Well, umm... They all wait for him to continue. He doesn’t. Just looks them, sweating.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: No video.  21.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: «+. No video? Marcus looks up and points to the surveillance camera abo the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Oh, we got cameras, but ... They wait for him to finish the sentence. He doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: VCR busted, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: They been planning to switch us over to a digital system that feeds right into the computer, these new cameras, they don’t hook to our VCR's. Need some kind of USB port.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Mmhmm. Turns to PARKER.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call over to the Young County Sheriff's, see if they just hit teller drawers and stuck to small bills, I’m sure they did, but -- and ask em if they thought to hook their cameras to some sort of recording device. PARKER dials his cell. Marcus turns to Mr. Clauson.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They armed?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Pistols.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Faces was covered?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CLAUSON
dialogues.text: Ski masks, long shirts, sweat shirts and baggy pants, like them thugs in Dallas.  22.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Tweakers maybe?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Little early in the morning for tweakers --

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: What the hell you talking about? Tweakers don’t sleep at all. They just ... Tweak. All day and all night. And think of ways to tweak some more -- like robbing banks.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: These boys ain’t tweakers. Tweakers rob drug stores and parked cars, not banks. Marcus spots Elsie, sitting on the steps, sweating bucket He walks to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You the teller? She looks up at him. Her face wearing the violation of th morning.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: They pushed me to the ground. Gun to my face. Made me sit on the floor. Her face curls at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the damn floor.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I know their faces was covered but could you tell their race? She just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Black? White?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Their skin or their souls?  Beat. 23.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Let’s leave their souls out of it for now.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: If it was two black men, they’d have never made it IN the bank ...

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: So they appeared Caucasian is what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: (Nodding) From around here somewhere is my guess. From their voices. PARKER walks up.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Young County says same deal.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: They got video? PARKER shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Same deal all the way around.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Doesn’t Wal-Mart sell all sorts of electronics? My word ... These boys ain't done, I’1l tell you that much.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: They're patient. Just hit the drawers and don’t take the hundreds cuz that’s the bank’s money -- you can trace that. They’re trying to raise a certain amount is my guess and it’s gonna take a few banks to get there at this rate. Besides ... Marcus looks at Mr. Clauson, Elsie, and the little bank.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is just too damn easy.  24. Marcus looks back over the small crowd -- all simple, cou folk, milling about in a state of grave disbelief. It’s a miracle people haven’t been robbing them non-stop for the past century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby and Tanner sit at a table scarfing chicken fried ste Through the window we see a WEST TEXAS STATE BANK branch. They are no longer dressed in baggy, urban gangster wear, like the poor country boys they are. Aside from a few old timers sipping coffee in a distant booth, the diner is empty.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You're boys know how rich they’re about to be?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: They don’t know anything.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You take ‘em to the funeral? A beat as they chew their food.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Like I said. They don’t know anything.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You haven’t told ‘em their grandmama died? (Toby just eats) When’s the last time you saw ‘em? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: When we all went to the rodeo in Stamford. Right after you got out. Tanner stops chewing.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That was last year. And that'll do it for Toby’s appetite. He sets his fork d  25.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I talk to ‘em on the phone. When Debbie’s not around ... It’s like time hooked a chain to ‘em, and it’s just ... pulling them away.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Want a little advice?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Go see ‘em tomorrow. In case this don’t work out, at least they’1l have a chance to do something if we get popped -- lord knows your spider of an ex-wife won’t let this go without a fight.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Got any idea how much I owe in child support? Debbie sees me walking up, she’ll have the sheriff on the phone before I ring the doorbell. When we’re done with this, I’1l see ‘em every day. Tanner laughs at his brother. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You got enough in your front pocket to fix that problem.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We'd have to add one to the list.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: So add one. Toby looks at his plate.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You talk like we ain’t gonna get away with this. Tanner leans into him.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I ain’t never met nobody who got away with anything. Ever. Have you?  26. Tanner smiles. Wipes his mouth with his napkin and tosses on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta shit like an old goat. Grab the check and meet me out front. And Tanner’s off. Toby swirls his almost empty tea, watching the few remain ice cubes travel around the bottom of the cup.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Boy, if that ain’t a hint, I don’t know what is. We look up at JENNY ANN, 29, a real looker when she was a teenager. Now, too plump to be called pretty, but still c and proudly displaying the one benefit of gaining fifty pounds. Her blouse can barely contain her breasts. She takes his cup and fills it. JENNY ANN (CONT’D) You like your steak?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: (Looking over his plate) Got a ways to go yet.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You'll be here all night waiting for me to finish this. She stands over him, smiling. INT. WEST TEXAS STATE BANK -- CONT. A young teller, this must be her summer job because she l sixteen, sits at her ‘window’ staring at a small black an white TV.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sure is quiet in here.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: Everyone’s at lunch, can I -- A ski mask stares back, pistol casually pointed at her.  27.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Open that drawer and take out the fives, tens, and twentys. Fan em out in front of me like a deck of cards. She does as he says. Looks at him, almost hyperventilatin

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your purse down there?

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: I don’t have any money.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Don’t want your money, darlin’. He smiles a toothy grin through the mask.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want your driver’s license. Hand it over. She fumbles for her purse, retrieves it. Hands him the license.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Depends. If you call the police -- Tanner looks over his shoulder to a glass office, a man sitting behind the desk, facing away from us.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or say anything to him, (He holds up the license) I’m gonna drive to your house and kill everyone I find. Understand? She frantically nods ‘yes’.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good girl. He smiles, his eyes lingering over her young body, watchi her breasts heave with every panicked breath.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re lucky I’m on a schedule. He turns and walks out. The girl leans back on her stool, gasping for air.  28. INT. DINER -- CONT.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (He lies) Last job was for a natural gas company.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: That sounds high dollar. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Nothing high dollar about drilling, and ... No one’s drilling for gas now anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: Well, they’re sure drilling for oil. Ain’t one drill the same as the next? He looks at her bright eyes and eager, almost flirty smil It makes him a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That's my take on it. Now I just gotta convince someone else to believe me.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: .- Somebody hiring. She tosses her considerable weight to one hip. We She sets the it. The look when another through this

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: could use a cook. check on the table. Her phone number written on on her face is one of coy desperation. Who knows handsome man even close to her age will wander town again.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just a thought. She stands there. He says nothing. Her coyness leaves her Only desperation remains. Finally, she walks off.  He looks at the bill: $18.49 29. He looks in her direction, pulls a wad of stolen money fr his pocket and counts out two hundred in twenties. EXT. DINER -- VERNON, TEXAS -- CONTINUOUS. Toby walks to the Taurus and looks up to see Tanner RUNNI toward him.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Start the car. Toby puts it together.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Shit. He jumps in the car and fires it up. Tanner jumps INT. TAURUS -- CONT. Toby heads straight for the side streets.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: WHAT DID I TELL YOU!!! YOU’RE GONNA GET US KILLED!!! THAT’S NOT A FIRST TEXAS BRANCH ... I must be out of my goddam mind to ask for your help on this. Tanner holds up a wad of cash.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Bet you don’t owe this much in child support. in. He doesn’t. Toby collapses his head against the seat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You just put us a goddam day behind. Tanner lights a cigarette. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. INT. WEST TEXAS STATE BANK -- A FEW MOMENTS LATER. The bank manager walks toward the teller, his head in a f  30.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: I need these copied in triplicate before we lock up -- He looks up to see the terrified girl, mascara running do her cheeks, shaking. He leans over the counter and sees t open, almost empty drawer. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) Did you hit the alarm? She just shivers. The manager leans his body over the counter and reaches h hand underneath, hitting a white button. The teller screa for all she’s worth and claws at his hands --

dialogues.speaker: NOOOOO
dialogues.text: INT. MARCUS’S LINCOLN -- LATE AFTERNOON. Marcus’s cell phone rings. He hands it to PARKER.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Can’t answer your own phone?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I’m driving, all your doin’ is twiddling your fat fingers.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Ranger Hamilton's phone (Listens, then looks at Marcus) Turn around. EXT. COUNTRY ROAD -- CONT. We watch as Marcus’s Lincoln whips around, heading back north... EXT. HANSON RANCH -- SUNSET. We watch Toby plant peach trees in the red dirt that now rests on the Taurus. Tanner sips a beer, standing under t shade of a large mesquite.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That one looks crooked, Toby. Could be a dead giveaway.  31. Tanner chuckles at his own joke. Toby marches toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Now we won’t make it to Lawton till damn near midnight and we have to stay over cuz we gotta get another goddam car first thing tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I‘ll still be drinking first thing tomorrow. How bout third thing? Toby storms off toward the house. Tanner empties his beer Tosses it on the ground, still laughing at his own joke a cracks open another. His smile disappears. With no one watching, his bravado leaves him too. He no longer looks dangerous. Just lonely ...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARCUS’S LINCOLN -- SUNSET. Marcus and PARKER head north on a two lane black top. Emptiness on either side of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Just over an hour between the first two, then wait all day to hit the bank in Vernon... Boy that’s bold, driving all over in a car with stolen money.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It’s reckless is what it is. Tweakers, I’m telling you.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I don’t think these boys is reckless. Damn sure ain’t tweakers. They know exactly what they’re doing. PARKER studies his partner.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: How in the world are you gonna survive without someone to out smart? You need a hobby and quick ... How bout a horse?  32.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Beth was the rider. A horse would just remind me of her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You like to fish?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Not enough to do it every goddam day.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: When I retire, I’m gonna move Esma and me to Galveston, and buy a fishing boat -- There’s these boats got a bedroom, kitchen, bathroom, everything. Like a floating apartment. Live on that sombitch right at the pier.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Guess you forgot about the hurricane that washed away the pier and the rest of Galveston with it.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: They're gonna rebuild it. I ain’t retiring next week, you are. The words stung more than either men expected. PARKER fum idly with the seat belt while Marcus stares straight ahea

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Who knows, maybe one of these bank robbers will want a gun fight, and I'll dodge retirement in a blaze of glory.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I seen you shoot. There won’t be much glory in it. Marcus laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Well, I’m lucky I got a half breed by my side to avenge me ... If you can stay sober enough to do it, knowing how you injuns like the bottle. PARKER laughs at the insult.  33.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Oh, you'd avenge me, would you? Marcus looks over at PARKER, dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I’d chase them all the way to hell and kill ‘em on the devil’s doorstep ... Take my damnation with a smile, my friend. We look out the windshield. Black smoke blocks out the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What in the hell is that? The road winds up a hill. They crest it and see: CATTLE, HUNDREDS OF THEM, STANDING IN THE ROAD. Marcus locks the brakes. The Lincoln slides and squeals t stop. They sit in silence, surrounded by cattle.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Good Lord, Marcus. COWBOYS on horseback race through the cattle, dismount, a frantically cut the barbed wire on the fence along the fa side of the road. Marcus leans out his window.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Hey, ya’ll burning this field?

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Why in the shit would we do that?? This kicked up along the highway. Wind keeps turning, goddam if it ain’t been chasing us for miles. Whichever way we go, this damn fire follows. The cowboy is on his horse and riding up toward Marcus’s window.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Wish we could do something for you.  34.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: It'd be easier if I just stood here and let it turn me to ashes. Put me out of my misery ... It’s the 21’st century and I’m racing a fire to the river with three hundred cattle. No wonder my kids don’t wanna do this nonsense for a living. The sun has set. The cowboy whistles and three dogs sprin from nowhere, nipping at the heels of the cattle. One dog jumps on the back of a cow, backlit by the dying sun. It’ silhouette runs from the back of one to another and anoth terrifying the exhausted cattle into action. The cattle moo and moan and move through the thirty-foot in the fence.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Wanna call it in?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: It’ll burn out when it hits the Brazos. No one to call around here anyway. These boys is on their own. The cattle pass, cowboys whooping and hollering behind th Marcus starts the car down the road, which is now covered cow shit. Marcus crests the rise in the road and the fire comes int view -- a vast expanse of smoldering black earth in its w ... Across the road, coyotes, one after the other, trot across the road. Up ahead a deer. Then another. And another. Seeking salva from the fire.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Looks like Noah’s Arc.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: If the Arc never showed.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Slow down. Marcus looks at him cross-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You see that fire to the left of us?  35.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: There’s animals all over the damn road and you’re -- The car jerks to a stop. Standing in the middle of the road in the headlights is a cougar. It looks at them like a man caught on the toilet. Turns to run back toward the fire, then turns again and b over the barbed wire fence, running off through the field

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never seen one of them before. Marcus’s face is one of wonder -- as though all this chao one last gift before the tedium of no purpose consumes hi

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Me neither. Marcus opens his door and steps out onto the road. Fire m toward them through the field, crawling low to the ground like a snake. As the dull orange of the setting sun disappears, the neo orange of the fire bleeds toward them like lava. Two more deer trot across the road. Through the headlight an exodus of dozens of rabbits.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: This is the craziest thing I ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanner drives as Toby rides shotgun. Country music keeps company. The air between them is thick. Tanner slows and turns onto a dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: What are you doing? We’re a day behind as it is.  36.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Casino ain't going nowhere. I need a few things (Off Toby’s look). My trailer’s right up here. Toby stews as the Blazer bounces down the dirt road. They turn onto an easement and come to a bump gate -- a spring mounted gate one bumps with the grill of a car, forcing the gate to open and very slowly close as a vehic passes through. They hit it, it pops back and they pull through.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Whose land is this?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Jeremy Chalker’s. Let’s me keep it here in exchange for killing coyotes. And any poachers who should wander this way. Tanner winks at him. They bounce past mesquites and junip and come to a tattered trailer. It is missing a rear whee the axle propped level with stacked wood. It is faded and filthy. A portable generator sits beside as do propane tanks and gas cans. The Blazer stops. Tanner hops out.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on in. Tanner disappears into the trailer. INT. TRAILER -- CONT. Toby steps into the ‘living area’. It is absolutely filth Clothes, fast food bags, empty beer cans everywhere. Toby almost holds his nose as he looks around.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s cold beer in the fridge. Toby goes to the fridge and grabs one. Anything to beat t stifling heat, made worse by standing in this tin box.  37. Toby notices a shelf that runs just beneath the ceiling. it are framed photos of them as boys, as teenagers, as yo men. They are the only things that are not broken or in disarray. He moves closer. Looks at them. One in particular: Tanner Toby on the front porch of the ranch house with their mot - her cold, unforgiving gaze, tempered by Toby's expressionless face, and Tanner -- all smiles. Toby looks at it, his face now washed with regret.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She looks meaner’n hell in that one, don’t she?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Don’t look happy. Tanner grins his devil grin.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That's cuz I was standing next to her. Grab this for me, will you? He hands a duffel bag to Toby. The weight of it jerks Tob arm down.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Toss it in the truck, I'll be right out. Toby exits and Tanner opens a small closet door, grabs an 15 assault rifle, and a scoped 30-06 ... EXT. TANNER’S TRAILER -- CONT. Toby tosses the bag in the back. Unzips it: ammo cans. Tanner walks out of the trailer carrying two rifle cases.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We don’t need those.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: They're my livelihood. Can’t just leave ‘em in the trailer for days on end.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Who’s gonna find ‘em out here?  38.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: No one now. Tanner places them in the back then climbs in the driver' seat. Toby turns and looks at the trailer -- This is how his brother lives. All he has to show for for two years of life. Toby shakes his head, all anger gone. in its place. He climbs in the Blazer, looks at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s the kindest we’ve heard Toby speak. EXT. GAS STATION -- HIGHWAY -- LATER. Tanner rests his feet on the dash while Toby pumps gas. T filled, Toby hangs up the pump.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You want anything?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Winston lights and a Dr. Pepper. Toby walks off. A NEW DODGE CHALLENGER, Painted to look vaguely like the Dukes of Hazard vehicle, pulls up in all soulless pretension. Behind the wheel is the post-modern version of white tras in his 20’s: head shaved, MMA tank top, and a mountain of attitude. How this dickhead afforded this car in the first place is mystery. Tanner looks over at him. The young punk stares back.

dialogues.speaker: PUNK
dialogues.text: What? Tanner smirks. Looks away.

dialogues.speaker: PUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What old man?  39. Tanner looks back at the steroid assisted build of this asshole, and his skinny buddy riding shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: PUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You looking for trouble, you came to the right place, mother fucker. Tanner turns lazily toward him, locks eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Boy, you'd think there was ten of me.

dialogues.speaker: PUNK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? The punk flashes a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: PUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not so fucking tough now, are you? The punk is stepping out when the car door is SLAMMED bac into him. The gun falls to the ground. Toby grabs the punk by his ears and pulls him halfway out window, then proceeds to pound his face with elbow after elbow. He does it with a speed and violence we did not ex of him. Tanner watches with a combination of amusement and affect Toby steps over to the passenger door while the punk hang unconscious from the driver's window. When Toby throws open the passenger door, he is met with raised hands and a look of terror.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY PUNK
dialogues.text: He had it coming! He had it coming! Toby slams the door and walks toward the Blazer. Tanner l back, feet still on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Look at you, got a little spunk left in you yet. Toby bends over and picks up the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And even remembered the gun. You’re becoming an old hand at this.  40.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: This asshole could have killed you. Tanner smiles and casually raises his own pistol.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Not the way it would've gone, little brother. Toby climbs in the passenger seat. Tanner starts the engi as the punk slowly comes to and looks up at Tanner, his broken nose bleeding profusely.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten of me. I told you. Tanner slams the Blazer in gear and they pull back on the road. INT. WEST TEXAS STATE BANK -- NIGHT. The teller is being comforted by two of her friends. A fe VERNON PD OFFICERS mill about. One receives a radio call. listens then approaches the teller.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON PD
dialogues.text: There’s an officer with your mama right now, she’s fine. You’re daddy’s on his way here. Marcus and PARKER push through the bank door. The officer spots them and moves in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON PD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's a little shook up. Perp took her driver's license. Threatened her family if she talked to us. Had a hell of a time finding them. Mama works in Wichita Falls and her daddy works on the Waggoner ranch.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That a fact. They reach the girl.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your name, young lady?

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: Natalie. Martinez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s gonna be officers watching your house extra careful till we catch these buggers, I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: There’s more than one??

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: «+. Only one man robbed the bank? She nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Dressed like a cowpoke, ‘cept for the ski mask.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Gloves?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Like a surgeon wears.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Other waiting in the car, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That's not the way they been doing it. Why change what works?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: He ran to a car parked out front of the cafe. They both turn.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You saw the car? She nods again.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Green, four doors.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: How old? Late model --

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know cars, mister.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Was it a nice car, an okay car, or a real piece of shit?  42. She looks him dead in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: A real piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Now we're getting somewhere. (Turns and sees the bank manager) That looks like a man who could foreclose on a house. Walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You the bank manager?

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yessir, I am.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Didn't happen to have your surveillance cameras on this morning, did you?

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Of course. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: So you got the robbery on video.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Of course we do. What kind of bank would we be if we didn’t have video surveillance?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: First Texas Bank. (Turns to PARKER and winks) We have video. Care to give it a watch while I wander over to the cafe?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Would you order me something while you're there? I’m starving.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I doubt they serve pemmican. PARKER has had enough.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You know, I’m half Mexican too.  43.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I’1ll get to that when I’m out of Indian insults. But it’s gonna be a while. Marcus turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: You Rangers are an odd bunch.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: No. Just him. INT. DINER -- VERNON, TEXAS -- NIGHT. Marcus steps through the door. The group of old men still sitting in the corner, waitresses peering through the win blinds at the activity across the street.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Evening.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Howdy.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I guess you’re aware of the doings at the bank.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I did notice.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Any out-of-towners come through today? The waitress nods.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Jenny Ann waited on a couple of old boys that ain’t from here.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: And where could I find Jenny Ann?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: She's in the back. I’1l go get her. She disappears into the kitchen. Marcus turns to the old He knows the answer to his question before he asks --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Ya'll been here for a while?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Long enough to watch someone rob the bank that’s been robbing me for thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You say you saw them?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Saw the guy running from the bank.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What’d he look like?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Had a mask on. But he ran pretty good, so I'd gather he’s youngish.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That so ... What’s youngish in your book?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Younger’n you and me, but older than all these little girls running around here pouring tea. Pretty sure they was sitting right over there, having lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That a fact. Can you describe them any better than youngish?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Tall, both of ‘em. Lean, like cowboys. Looked like brothers if you ask me. One had a mustache and scruff, other one was clean shaved. Scruffy one looked like trouble. Other one just looked like a old country boy. Jenny Ann walks up to him. Looks at his badge.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: Texas Ranger?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. Tell me bout these handsome young strangers you waited on.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: Who said handsome?  Beat. 45.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I did. Based on the fact you didn’t meet me in the parking lot hollering about the two out of towners eating here right before a bank robbery.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: They never mentioned they was robbing the bank.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Pay cash for their dinner?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: That a crime now?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: How much they leave?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: Two hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Can I see the bills they paid with?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: Not a chance in hell.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That’s evidence.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY ANN
dialogues.text: It’s evidence if they’re the bank robbers. Till then it’s my tip. Her eyes grow fierce. JENNY ANN (CONT’D) And half my mortgage. So you go get a warrant and come after the money I'll be using to keep a roof over my daughter’s head. She turns and shakes her big ass back to the kitchen. The men laugh.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: She's a tiger, that one.  PARKER comes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Just one man hit the bank, like she said. Checkered button down shirt. Jeans. Ski mask. That’s about all the video tells us. Marcus looks over at the old timer.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Yep. Checkered shirt. That’s him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (Pointing to the table by the window) They was eatin’ right over there. Tipped her two hundred dollars. Marcus smiles as he looks toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go wrestle a description from the sassy fat girl in the kitchen. And get that tip from her. We’re gonna check them bills.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: (To PARKER) Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’d expect some resistance .-. And call that Best Western on 287 and grab us a room.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: We're stayin’ the night? Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: This is where all the action is. PARKER shakes his head and moves toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Sure seems foolish ... The days of robbing banks and living to spend the money’s long gone, ain’t they? ... Long gone for sure. 46.  47. His friends nod in agreement, almost sadly. Marcus looks over, knowing they will be dead in a few years -- knowing and dominos and death is his future too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby drives, Tanner is sprawled out in the front seat. Ye lines race underneath the hood in the dim glow of the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: What does Justin want to do when he’s grown?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Right now he’s just focusing on slinging a football for A&M.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That’s what did me in.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: He’s a lot like you.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Bet that puckers yer red eye. Toby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: More than you know.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Forty two years of life, ten of em in prison ... If he’ll just turn left where I turned right, he’1l be okay. George Strait comes through the speakers.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “COLD FORT WORTH BEER, JUST AIN'T

dialogues.speaker: NO GOOD FOR JEALOUS --
dialogues.text: Tanner leans into him, close to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “I TRIED IT NIGHT AFTER NIGHT.”  48. Toby tries to suppress a grin. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: If you don’t think we can get away with this, why’d you agree to do it? Tanner lights a cigarette. Cracks the window.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Cuz you asked, little brother. Toby looks at Tanner -- a living testament to self destruction -- and absorbs both the simplicity and weight the statement. The neon lights of THE COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO invade t night sky and flood the road with yellows, reds, and gree Tanner comes to life at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My God that’s pretty. How we entertained ourselves before they let Indians open casinos, I'll never know.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Just ... We’re here to change the money, not lose everything at the blackjack table.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Blackjack’s for old women. I’11l leave that to you -- hold ‘em, baby. TEXAS HOLD ‘EM YOU SONS OF

dialogues.speaker: BITCHES
dialogues.text: Toby can’t help but smile as the virus of Tanner’s excite invades him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chimes of slot machines fills the air as does the ene of people desperate to win what they can’t earn. Toby and Tanner stand in line to check in. Tanner is almo childlike with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Get drunk with me.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m not gettin’ drunk --

dialogues.speaker: OH, MAN ROBBING BANKS IS HARD WORK,
dialogues.text: I’M PLUM WORE OUT FROM --

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You think that’s funny?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We’re gonna remember this forever, Toby. Tanner smiles like a child.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: This ain’t supposed to be fun.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Well, it’s gonna be. It’s their turn. An attractive front desk clerk greets th

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Comanche Red River Casino, do you have a reservation?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We do not -- dear lord, look at you --(Pretends to adjust a neck tie) we would be obliged if you would provide us accommodations, though we failed to call ahead. The clerk smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: He’s gonna be feisty, isn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That’s one way of putting it. There is a stack of books displayed at the check in. A bl and white photo of the great Comanche Chief QUANAH PARKER the cover. Tanner notices and points to the title --

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Lords of the Plains. Tanner grabs a copy.  50.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll take this too. You Comanche?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Is that right. His eyes penetrate her, she blushes.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We just need a, umm ... credit card for incidentals and if you could fill out these... She hands them room forms.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We'll be paying cash.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We still need a credit card for authorization. Tanner puts a thousand dollars on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: How bout we leave Mastercard out of it. He winks at her.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You're trouble.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: The worst kind, darlin’. In your last days at the nursing home, you'll think of me and giggle. She doesn’t wait for the nursing home -- she’s giggling n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stare into a shot glass. It’s raised and thrown toward past us. We turn around and watch Toby and Tanner slam sh glasses on the counter. Toby winces, Tanner could drain a bottle.  51.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: NOW WE’RE TALKING.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (To the bartender) Can I grab a beer?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Man, look at the women in this son of a bitch. We take a look around and have no idea who Tanner is referring to. The women we see are either obese or beaten the sun and alcohol to the point they look leather.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You're kidding me, right?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Let’s get another shot... They’1l be pretty soon enough. BARTENDER!

dialogues.speaker: WHISKY IF YOU PLEASE
dialogues.text: Shots are poured. Tanner grabs his and raises it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To your boys. And the future we’re giving ‘em. Toby reluctantly raises his glass. Tanner touches his to Toby’s. Then slams it back.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s change this money and have some fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARRY KING is interviewing PARIS HILTON.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY KING
dialogues.text: And how old is Tinkerbell? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I don’t umm ... I don’t know. Old, like eight or something.  52.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why couldn’t we drive back to Abilene?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cuz they ain’t robbing banks in Abilene.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY KING
dialogues.text: And she’s the focus of your new book called...

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You mind if I change the channel before my head explodes? Marcus and PARKER lay in separate queen beds, wearing the undershirts and staring at the boob box.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Sure. PARKER surfs. Finds PAT ROBERTSON screaming about Obama a Satan. One in the same, based on Pat’s diatribe. MARCUS (CONT’D) We ain’t gonna watch this, are we?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Ain’t you Christian?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I am, but I ain’t stupid. God doesn’t talk through this man any more than he does through my dog.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Then maybe you should give your dog a listen.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Ain’t you Indian? You’re supposed to be burning sage and dancing around the bed whooping like a bee stung you.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I’m Catholic.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I'd rather dance around a fire with a spear -- hell, I’d rather you stab me with a spear than watch this. Change the channel.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I'd like a little God in my ears before I go to sleep --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Then open the window and listen to the wind. PARKER changes the channel to ESPN.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Happy? They are replaying highlights from the University of Texa first game of the year.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: This is what God watches. PARKER clouds.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, they’ll have soccer highlights soon enough. That’s for your Mexican half. PARKER turns from the TV. Buries his head in his pillow. Marcus is glued to the tube.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Look at that boy run. Longhorns gonna have a good team this year. I’ll never understand that soccer. Anything a five year old can do ain't a sport. PARKER shifts in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who invented soccer, the Aztecs? Kicking around skulls or something? That sounds like a Comanche sport. PARKER tosses the remote in Marcus’s general direction. Marcus grabs it and cradles it like an egg. Victorious.  54.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: In three weeks you can watch TV all day.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You know what’s funny, Alberto? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: ... What.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: In a year’s time, it’s my teasing you'll miss. It’s what you’ll laugh about when you stand over my grave and wish me well.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: God, I hope that’s tomorrow. Marcus gives a hearty laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That’s a good one. You’ll get the hang of this yet. PARKER pulls the covers up higher, trying like hell not t like this old bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby counts out one, two, three, four, five thousand doll in twenties and tens. He looks at the window teller and lies.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Sorry. I sold my car and this is how the fella paid me.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW TELLER
dialogues.text: We take it any way you bring it, mister. She takes the money, puts it in a money counter, and slid him ten thousand dollars in chips. WINDOW TELLER (CONT’D) (Knowing it won’t help) Good luck.  55. They walk from the window. Toby hands his brother a chip tray.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Just like that. No trace. Don’t lose it all.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Take your own advice.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I don’t gamble. Tanner has a laugh at that.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You wanna come to the poker table? Can’t no one lose money at poker, not even you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna watch the Aggie game and have a beer.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Suit yerself. And Tanner’s off. Toby looks around. He heads to the bar. Orders a beer and looks out over the casino. INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- POKER TABLE -- NIGHT. Tanner is at the no limit hold ‘em table, an enormous sta of chips before him -- he’s almost doubled his money. Cards are dealt. Tanner peaks at his. Pocket Cowboys. The betting starts. Everyone calling the initial bet of $200.00. Everyone but Tanner, who raises to a thousand. All eyes are on him. He meets them with a ‘try me’ look. do. The chips are pushed toward him. He smiles. A winner ... INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- BAR -- NIGHT. Toby sits at the bar, watching a football game. Beside hi sits a woman, clearly a hooker, though a decent looking o  56. She stares at his chip trays. She slides a few bar stools toward him.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Quite a stack. Toby looks over at her. It’s clear what she is, but she Manages to make that part of her appeal.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, been pretty lucky. She slides closer.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: No. When lucky men win, they hurry home like a scalded dog. Men that can gamble and keep their money ... That’s a smart man. He looks her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Not much of a character study, are you?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, studying character’s my profession.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That's not the profession I was figuring for you. She smiles and leans into him.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: No? What did you figure? INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- POKER TABLE -- NIGHT. Tanner’s chip stack has grown even more. And right now, h a got a fair pile in the middle. He has a five and six of clubs. On the flop we see a seve hearts, an eight of diamonds, and a nine of spades. Tanne flopped the straight. He tosses more chips in the pot, running everyone else of but -- A GIGANTIC, COMANCHE MAN in his 50’s. Sunglasses. The BIG MAN stares at the flop. Looks at Tanner. Tanner smiles. The BIG MAN calls him.  57. Fourth street: jack of Diamonds. Tanner throws five hundred in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Don’t chase me, chief. I’m already there. Mirrored shades stare back. ‘Chief’ didn’t sit well. He raises him 500. Tanner laughs and calls. The dealer tosses the river card: a five of diamonds. Tan knows he just got beat. So does the BIG MAN.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: I check to the chief. Tanner’s eyes run cold. He stares at the BIG MAN. The BIG removes his glasses: five centuries of hate stare back. Tanner looks like he might kill this man right here. In f of everyone. And the BIG MAN looks ready for it. The dealer says possibly the worst thing he could at the absolute worst time:

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Bet’s to you, sir. Tanner ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You Comanche? The BIG MAN nods.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lords of the Plains.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: Lords of nothing now. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I bet a thousand. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: You can’t beat me.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I know.  58.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: What if I raise? Tanner smiles an evil smile.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Be careful. The BIG MAN knows the raise was an apology. He also knows he raises, he’ll have to fight this lunatic for his life.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: I call. The dealer lets an audible sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Show your cards, gentlemen. The BIG MAN turns over his flush.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: What’s the Comanche word for warrior? The BIG MAN smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: Comanche. We are all warriors. Tanner nods. Stands.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I’m a warrior too.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: Hope you fare better than we did.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Doing okay so far. Tanner grabs his chip trays and rises. The BIG MAN puts h sunglasses back on.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: Know what Comanche means? It means ‘enemies forever’.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Enemies with who?

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: Everyone.  59. Tanner takes that in.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Know what that makes me?

dialogues.speaker: BIG MAN
dialogues.text: An enemy.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: No. Tanner leans across the table, inches from the BIG MAN’s face. Whispers like he’s telling him a secret.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It makes me a Comanche. Tanner looks into the mirrored shades, his own reflection staring back. He rises and walks away. INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- BAR -- NIGHT. The hooker sits next to Toby now, pressing her bare leg against him. He isn’t used to women this attractive who a this aggressive. He teeters between wariness and fascinat

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Does he look like you?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I see his mama in him, everyone else sees me ... I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: He’s lucky if he does, I'll say that. She leans into him, her lips against his ear.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You staying in the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: «+. Yeah. She purrs.  60.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Take me to your room. He looks at her, knows he’s being worked. But it feels so good to have a woman next to him. It’s been so long.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Look, I’m, thank you, but ... I’m not here for me. As foolish as it sounds, he says it anyway:

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m trying to do something noble for once, and -- She puts a finger to his lips, then lets that finger run his lip to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: There’s no shame in needing the touch of a woman. She puts a hand to his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need it, I know you do. How long has it been? (She is inches from his mouth) Let me touch you -- Something jerks her away. Toby looks up to find: Tanner h her by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Tryin’ to work my little brother, are you? As an astute judge of character, she knows instantly what kind of man she is now dealing with, and acts accordingly which is to say submissive and scared to death.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I wasn’t doing anything but --

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: But but but. You spied that stack of chips and saw an easy mark -- don’t get me wrong, no one likes a whore more than I do( he pulls her close), But those are my chips, you wanna try and steal from me? She shakes her head ‘no’.  61.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: She wasn’t doin’ nothing. Tanner stares into the eyes of the terrified young woman.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Gonna get him in a room and what, call your pimp and roll him? Drug him, what?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Hey, come on --

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: No, I -- Tanner looks around the empty bar, still gripping the hooker’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Where is he? Where’s the man that holds your leash? No one in the bar fits the bill. The bartender watches th while pretending he isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll just sample the goods real quick. Tanner peals off a couple of hundreds from his wad, works hand up her dress, looking her in the eye, while he runs money inside her underwear. Toby stands up. Grabs Tanner’s arm and pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Let her go.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: (Into her ear) Merry Christmas. She steps back from both of them, turns, and hauls ass.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You're fucking crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Call me!(whips Around to Toby) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: How the fuck have you stayed out of prison for a year??  62. Big grin from Tanner.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: It’s been a challenge (Sizes up his brother) Let’s go change it back then ... Fun’s all over now.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Not supposed to be fun.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Well you’re goddam makin’ sure of that. Tanner walks off. Toby scans the bar, exhales, then reluctantly follows. INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- CHIP WINDOW -- NIGHT. They cash in their chips, now totalling twenty nine thous dollars.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW TELLER 2
dialogues.text: You’1l need to fill out this tax form. Over twenty thousand, you have the option of receiving your money in a cashier’s check.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I'll take ten in cash. The rest in a check.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW TELLER 2
