dialogues.text: You want that made out to you?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: No. First Texas Bank. She places a check in the check printer, hits a button, a voila -- money laundered. She hands the check and cash to Toby.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go to the room.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think that’s one hell of an idea. Toby turns back and follows Tanner’s gaze to the pretty h clerk -- now in street clothes -- smiling at Tanner, and walking toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus wakes to a terrible pain in his upper chest. He si up. Reaches for a bottle of Tums on the night stand. Grab hand full.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Heart burn. I'll be fine. Marcus rises, goes to the sink. Gets a drink. The pain hi him. Tries to shake it off. Stares at himself, suffering the mirror. EXT. BEST WESTERN -- VERNON, TEXAS -- NIGHT. Marcus, dressed in his undershirt, jeans, and boots, step outside and walks toward the field behind the motel. He l out over the mesquites and cactus. The warm air helps. Or maybe its just the walk. He looks at the sky -- clouds and ten thousand stars carpet the ni An owl hoots. Flies over him. He watches the dark image m silently over him. Marcus walks toward a barbed wire fence, rests against it The warm air blows against him, pushing him like a tatter sail. Marcus looks to the stars as he leans into the wind tries to laugh off his suffering.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: This is the thanks I get? Rotting from the inside out. After all I done for you... He looks out over the mesquites, who answer back in an an whistle as the wind whips through their leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby brushes his teeth as Tanner lays in bed, the hotel c beside him, reading LORD OF THE PLAINS.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Boy, you Comanches were the real deal. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (To Toby) You wanna hear what they did to the people they took captive?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Damn right you don’t. Not a inch of mercy in them. (To the girl) You gonna show me any mercy, darlin’?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Not an inch.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You're right ... I’m gonna go see my boys tomorrow. Toby climbs into his bed and rolls away from Tanner and t clerk. Tanner clicks off the lamp. The clerk climbs on to him. Though she still wears her shirt, she is completely naked from the waist down. She presses her pelvis into hi she kisses him deeply.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I’m expecting a lot from you. Tanner presses into her and she moans.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: What do you call that? Toby knows there will be no sleep with this a bed over. H sits up, pulls his jeans back on ... EXT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- NIGHT. Toby walks through the parking lot, past semi’s and motor homes, toward the edge of the prairie. From here, it exte out forever. He walks through the grass, looking up at the same stars Marcus pondered. Looks back at the casino, its harsh neon lights violating the horizon. He turns back to the solace of the dark plains, and keeps walking ...  65. EXT. BEST WESTERN -- VERNON, TEXAS -- DAWN. Marcus sits in a cheap lawn chair in front of the motel, watching the sun come up over the highway. A few trucks blast by as he watches. The motel room door opens. PARKER stands in boxers and a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: What’re you doing? Marcus talks without looking back at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Watching the sun rise. Sitting on a porch. Practicing for my future.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It’s a dangerous thing we do for a living. You’re lucky to have seen it through to the end. Hope I’m that lucky.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Without me by your side, I doubt you'll get close enough to a criminal to ever be in danger again. PARKER’s face clouds.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Just when I was staring to feel sorry for you. Marcus stands, and looks at PARKER for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Indians ain’t supposed to feel sorry for cowboys. It’s the other way around. PARKER looks into Marcus’s eyes, red and swollen from cry Marcus brushes past him and walks into the motel room. EXT. USED CAR LOT -- LAWTON, OKLAHOMA -- DAWN. We stare at the engine of a red Pontiac Grand Am as it re Toby is beneath it with a flashlight, studying. It is far early for anything legal to be happening on a used car lo  66.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Put it in gear. We hear it kick into drive. Toby stands up.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sounds good. Let me give it a spin. Tanner gets out of the driver’s seat. Toby gets in and dr the Pontiac off. Standing across from Tanner is BUSTER ME 45, used car salesman in every sense.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: We doing this one the same?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You got plates for it?

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Ain’t got no more Texas plates. I got Arkansas, Kansas, New Mexico --

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: New Mexico works. Don’t report this stolen till Friday.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Friday, okay. Toby pulls back in.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: How is it?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Runs good. Don’t like that it’s red.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: He’s got New Mexico plates for it, though. Toby takes that in.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We’re in business.  67. Buster walks off to start the paperwork. Tanner goes to t Blazer, grabs the duffel and the rifle cases, and tosses in the Grand Am.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You okay meeting the guy from Chevron by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You okay seeing Debbie by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I'll manage. Remember, this guy ain’t the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Oh, the oil man’s the enemy, make no mistake, he just ain’t ours.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’ll be back to the ranch by dark.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I’ll be there.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (Points at the Grand Am) Arrest me red. You better drive like a school teacher. Toby climbs in the Blazer and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and PARKER sit at a table. The ceilings are easily twenty feet high, old cedar beams criss crossing it, ceil fans hanging down, circulating hot air. Through the large window, we see a FIRST TEXAS BANK. On the wall hangs a plaque dedicated to the soldiers from Coleman who have fought and died for this country. So man names, one would think the whole town died for our freedo

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: What’s the plan?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: We’re gonna watch that bank like a deer feeder ...  68. Marcus scans the restaurant, looks out the front window a over the little square with almost no life in it.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This little town fits their bill, based on the ones they hit so far. Got a bank and not much else. So we'll just sit here and wait. In time we’ll be right. A waitress, she must be ninety years old, walks up.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Ya'll are a might early for lunch, ain’t you? It’s not even eleven.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Howdy ma’am. How are you today? She casts a mean glare at Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Hot. And not the good kind. What don’t you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: What don’t you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Well, I was thinking I’d just get the --

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I been working here forty-four years. Only thing anyone’s ever ordered is the T-Bone steak and a baked potato. ‘Cept some asshole from New York who tried to order trout in 1987. We don’t sell no goddam trout. Don’t have nuthin but T-bones. So, you either don’t want the corn on the cob, or you don’t want the green beans, so what don’t you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I don’t want green beans. She looks at PARKER.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I don’t want green beans either.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Steaks cooked medium rare.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Could I have mine --

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: That weren't a question. Beat. WAITRESS (CONT’D) Tea for you boys to drink.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Tea’s great.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. She storms off.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell you one thing. Ain’t no one robbing this son of a bitch ... My word. EXT. DEBBIE'S HOUSE -- CHILDRESS, TX -- DAY. DEBBIE HANSON, late 30's, quite the looker four kids ago, attempts to fold laundry while her 6 month old baby cries She surrenders to the screams and picks up the baby.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What? What? Are you wet? She checks. DEBBIE (CONT’D) Nope ... Your little gums hurt, that it? The doorbell chimes. She shakes her head in amazement at chaos of her life. She heads to the door. Opens it. Toby stands there. Anger washes over her face. DEBBIE (CONT’D) If you don’t have thirty five hundred dollars I’m calling the --  He holds up the cash.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you want? Toby looks at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: One of the few mistakes in my life you're not responsible for. What do you want. Toby takes a minute to digest this.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It’s been that long since I’ve seen you?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What do you want.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’d like to say hi to the boys if I could. She motions to the money.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Do I want to know where that came from?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Not if you want to keep it. She almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Come on in. 70. The place is modest on its very best day. But it is tidy. He does.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put the money on the table and I’1l offer you a beer.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Mama died.  71. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: When.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Last week.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, good riddance. No offense. Guess you'll be selling the ranch.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It goes to the boys. Debbie’s eyes light a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It’s being put in a trust.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Means you can’t sell it. Those eyes turn dark.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Great. Something else I gotta take care of. Around the corner comes JUSTIN HANSON, 14, kind face of h father, wild eyes of his uncle. Built to play football. H rounds the corner. Freezes when he sees Toby.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (To Debbie) Give me two beers. EXT. DEBBIE'S HOUSE -- BACK PORCH -- DAY. Toby and Justin sit on shitty lawn chairs overlooking a y of weeds.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Where’s your brother?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t know. A friend’s house I guess.  72.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: How come you ain’t at school?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t start for a week. Just two-a- days for football right now. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You should mow this lawn for your mama.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Ain’t got a lawn mower. It is awkward. Tense. Might as well get to it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Your grandmother died. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m giving the ranch to you and your brother. You remember going out there when you was little?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. What am I supposed to do with a ranch?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Anything but sell it. Toby leans close to Justin. Whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We found oil on it. He let’s that sit.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You and Randy ain’t gonna have to worry about money no more. He looks at his boy.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna hear a lot of things about me ... And your uncle. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be like us. Be smart. Look out for your brother. Justin nods.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Whatever I hear I won’t believe.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Believe it. Cuz I did all of it. Now you do it different. Don’t let your mother have any say in the money you boys get. She got a decent heart, but she can’t be trusted where money’s concerned ... If I’m not sitting here with you on Friday, tell her everything I just said, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Okay. Toby looks at Justin’s full beer.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Ain’t gonna drink it? It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: You tell me not to be like you then you offer me a beer. Which is it? Toby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Good boy. He puts his hand on Justin’s shoulder. Justin Lets him. EXT. HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- DAY. Tanner sits on the front porch, twelve pack of Bud by his side. Empties litter the ground around him, though he isn drunk. He’s been immune to beer for decades. Across his lap is the AR 15 assault rifle. He has it most disassembled and is in the process of placing three penni behind the firing pin, making a semiautomatic rifle a mac gun. He reassembles the rifle and sets it by the scoped 30-06. Tanner picks up a rifle magazine and begins clicking roun into it from an army box of easily a thousand rounds.  74. On the table, we see another twenty rifle magazines, wait to be fed. As he loads, he sings an old Waylon Jennings s

dialogues.speaker: LONG AGO AND FAR AWAY. IN MY OLD
dialogues.text: COMMON LABORER’S SHOES ... I TURNED

dialogues.speaker: BECAUSE YOU ASKED ME TOO ...
dialogues.text: He sets the loaded magazine down, and picks up another, begins loading, and sings the chorus:

dialogues.speaker: LET THE WORLD CALL ME A FOOL, BUT
dialogues.text: IF THINGS AIN'T RIGHT ‘TWEEN ME AND YOU ... IT’S ALL THAT MATTERS AND I'LL DO ... ANYTHING YOU ASK ME TO. Tanner spots the Blazer driving up the dirt road. He walk out to meet it. Toby stops and gets out. Sees the rifles propped beside h

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How were your boys? Toby points to the rifles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Insurance. If we can’t get enough from the branch in Jayton, we're gonna have to hit the one in Post. Post is a long way from home. The branch in Childress, well, can’t hit the branch there. For obvious reasons. And if you don’t want to hit the branch in Coleman ...

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We can’t go back to the casino in Oklahoma now. Gotta head west, gotta be the one in New Mexico. Toby points to the rifles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want all that shit in the car and we damn sure don’t need it. What if we get pulled over?  75.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We’re running two cars on the next one, brother. They’1l ride with me. You head to the casino in Riudoso and I’ll head north. They’re looking for two. No one robs a bank in separate cars ... It’s smart, Toby. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It is. But I still don’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: It’s not to like, just to do. Toby points to the rifles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We're not bringing them in the bank... Oil man come by?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: They’re ready to go. When you pay that loan officer he’s gotta give you a form that shows a release of lien or something.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You fax it over, and you’re done.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We gotta go meet the lawyer. Tanner downs his beer.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Waitin’ on you. EXT. RAYBURN LAW OFFICE -- SEYMOUR, TEXAS -- DAY. Tanner and Toby sit across from BILLY RAYBURN, 40'S, lawy handsome, and wearing the West Texas version of a suit: Jeans, blazer, and boots. Billy hands Toby a stack of papers.  76.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Initial in the boxes, and sign at the bottom. There’s three copies, gotta do the same to each.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: And this makes you the executor.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: So no matter what they charge us with, they can’t take it away.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: There’s no way to trace funds from a casino. Once you get the checks to the bank, the trust is untouchable.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: And you can’t tell nobody nuthin’, right?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s to tell? You boys won the money gambling, right? Tanner smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thirty two thousand pays off the reverse mortgage and those bastards paid the property taxes from 2007 to now, that’s another eleven thousand. Forty three thousand and you're free and clear. Have the loan officer fax me the lien release and I’1l get it over to the lease manager at Chevron. He hands Toby a business card.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fax number’s on the card.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: How much you gonna make off this deal?  77.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not near as much as I’m risking.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Then why do it? He looks at Tanner.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: How long we known each other?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Since ... I don’t know. Always.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: --. It’s the insult of it. That ranch is worth a half million without the oil, but they loaned the least they could get away with, just enough to keep your mama poor, on a guaranteed return. Thought they could swipe that land from you boys and suck on that oil for twenty five thousand dollars. It’s just so arrogant it makes my teeth hurt ... To watch you pay those bastards with their own money ... (He laughs at the thought) If that ain’t Texan I don’t know what is. Toby stands and offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: They can foreclose on Friday. Come hell or high water you be at the bank in Childress before they close Thursday. And knowing them fuckers, they’1l close early.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We'll be there. They rise to leave.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Toby. The trust needs to be managed by a bank ... You really wanna cover your tracks? Billy smiles.  78. EXT. T BONES CAFE -- COLEMAN, TEXAS -- DAY. The sun is setting as Marcus and PARKER sit on a bench un a Texas Porch that runs the length of the block.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: All these little towns. Dying. What do you think’1l happen to ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: This is your plan? Just sit here and see if this is the branch they rob next ... Marcus looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Not much of a thinker, are you?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Do you want to live here? Old hardware store that charges twice what Home Depot does? One restaurant with a rattlesnake for a waitress? How are you supposed to make a living here?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: People made a living here for a hundred and fifty years.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: People lived in caves for a hundred thousand years, but don’t do it no more, and they’re the better for it. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Maybe your people did. Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You're people did too. Long time ago, your ancestors was the Indians and someone else came along and killed ‘em or broke ‘em down and made you into one of them. A hundred and fifty years ago, all this was MY ancestors’ land. Everything you can see. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything you saw yesterday. This was all Comancheria. Till the grandparents of all these folks took it. Now it’s being taken from them. Except it ain’t no army doing it. (PARKER points at the bank) It’s that son of a bitch, right there. Marcus studies his partner.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: And here I am thinking you was slow as a two-legged turtle.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I may be. But that don’t make it any less true. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: These boys should've hit this branch by now.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Then why are we still sitting here?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Just cuz ... I like this little town.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I know what you’re doing. You’re tryin’ to make this last as long as you can. Cuz the longer it lasts the farther you are from your front porch ... That ain’t fair --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: To who? The bank? Only thing we can do is wait for these boys to make a mistake, and so far they ain’t. So relax. Enjoy this little town. From everything I see, it’ll die long before I do. They look out over the empty square, watching squirrels feasting underneath the pecan trees in the empty town squ as the sun dips below the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby and Tanner sit on the porch, staring at the stars as pack of coyotes whimpers and yips somewhere in the distan

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Thinking about tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Ain't you? Tanner shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That little hotel clerk. Why’s it always the sweet ones that’s such devils when you get ‘em revved up?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Never been with a sweet one. Tanner laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That's right. You like ‘em pissed off and looking for someone they can blame it on. Toby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Sure seems that way, don’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: This is a good thing you’re doing. You know that?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We're doing it. Tanner grins and winks.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go easy on the tellers tomorrow, okay?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I’ll be as gentle as young nurse. Tanner stands up, stretches, and yawns.  81.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wake me up at five.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yep. Tanner disappears inside. Leaving Toby alone. He sits bac his mind running all the possibilities. How it can go rig How it can go wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crickets are chirping so loud, it echoes off the old, stone building. It doesn’t appear Marcus has moved in hou still staring out over the square. Across the way, PARKER carrying his suitcase into a motel. Marcus takes out his can of Copenhagen, packs it, and pla a pinch in his cheek. Ready for a long night of reflectio INT. HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- KITCHEN -- NIGHT. The wall clock says ten after five in the morning. Toby s dressed like a gang banger, pistol and three magazines fo on the table. He sips coffee as Tanner walks in dressed t same.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I’ll never understand how those gang bangers can walk around with their pants like this, dangling off their asses. No wonder they always get caught when they run from the police. Toby slides him a cup of coffee. Tanner sits. They drink their coffee in silence.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Want some breakfast? Tanner thinks that one over.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Breakfast sounds good. Toby stands and heads to the fridge. Pulls out bacon and carton of eggs. Crosses over to the stove. Tanner watches brother as he cooks.  82.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you do this for mama?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Every morning. She didn’t eat much the last month.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Did you used to cook breakfast for your boys? Toby stops.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah ... Been a long time, though. Tanner sits back in his chair, like a child, patiently waiting for his meal.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You do the bacon first, then the eggs in the grease, right?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yep. That’s the way. Tanner watches his brother and sips his coffee as the bac begins to sizzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cars move toward us. The blazer and the Grand Am. Headlights on, though morning is breaking. They come clos Closer ... EXT. T BONES CAFE -- COLEMAN, TEXAS -- DAY. PARKER stands over us, looking down at something, shaking head in disbelief at -- Marcus, asleep on the bench, chin to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: For someone who don’t want to spend his days sittin’ on his porch, you sure don’t mind lounging on everybody else’s.  83. Marcus stirs. Looks up at PARKER who hands him coffee ina Styrofoam cup..

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Just ... Didn’t see the point in walking all the way to the motel just to walk back here in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Who’s not much of a thinker now? PARKER sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Restaurant don’t open for another hour. And the two men begin their day where the last one ended, staring at the empty square. EXT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- JAYTON, TEXAS -- DAY. Toby and Tanner stand in front of the bank, ski masks on. They don’t move. Just stare straight ahead. We look over their shoulder and see why: The Jayton Branch is closed. Doors wrapped in chain and locked. Windows covered with large plywood boards.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We gotta hit the branch in Post.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We won’t get there till after ten.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We don’t got a choice. Gotta have that money to the branch in Childress before they close tomorrow. Toby shakes his head as he pulls off his mask.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We don’t know Post. Don’t know the patterns of the folks out there.  84.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Pattern’s the same as it is everywhere. All these towns is dead. Post ain’t no different. Let's go. They turn and walk out of frame, leaving us to stare at t closed bank in a closed town. INT. T BONE’S CAFE -- DAY. Marcus and PARKER sit sipping coffee, looking over a map Texas.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: First two banks were First Texas branches. There’s seven total: main branch in Fort Worth, and they ain’t messing with that. The branch in Olney they hit, the one in Archer City they hit, the one here, the one in Childress, Jayton --

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: That one’s closed.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Okay. That leaves the branch in Post. Childress is a decent sized town, I don’t think they’11 mess with that.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: The branch in Vernon wasn’t First Texas and they hit that.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: One of ‘em did. Alone. And then ran all the way across the square to get back to the car. I think his partner had no idea that was gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: What does that mean to us?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: It means the only other First Texas branch that fits the bill is in Post.  85.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: There’s plenty of little banks in other towns --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: And they’d have robbed ‘em by now if they was interested in other banks, but they ain’t. They’re after First Texas’s money and that’s the only place they can get it that makes any sense.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It’s three hours away. If you wanna head that way we should get on the road. They both stand, Marcus tossing a twenty on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Let’s get some troopers moving in that direction ... I’m feelin’ lucky. They move off toward the door, pushing it open, and flood the restaurant with the blinding Texas sun. EXT. STATE HIGHWAY 308 -- DAY. The Blazer and Grand Am drive through the ragged land bel the CAP ROCK: a geological marvel where the great plains plummet four hundred feet along a fault line, creating a cliff that dissects West Texas. On one side of the road is an endless wall of red dirt. O the other: land so broken it looks as though God stabbed repeatedly with two giant shovels, punishing it for some unknown offense. The cars breeze by us, the Cap Rock wall towering beside them. EXT. HIGHWAY 308 -- OUTSIDE POST, TEXAS -- DAY. Both vehicles pull off the road. Toby gets out of the Bla and jogs to the Grand Am. He gets in. The Pontiac pulls b on the road, past a sign that reads: POST - 3 MILES.  86. EXT. MAIN STREET -- POST, TEXAS -- DAY. There are actual signs of life here. A few cars in front the grocery store. Pick up trucks in front of the diner. and trucks at the gas station. The FIRST TEXAS BANK sign looms in the distance. INT. GRAND AM -- CONT.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: This town looks busy.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Little bit. Look at the bank though. Not a car in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We do this quick.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Gotta take the hundreds this time.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Make sure they fan ‘em out in front of you. If an ink pack gets in the bag, that money’s useless.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yep. They park in front of the bank. No other cars around. We watch from a distance as they get out and hurry inside, pulling on their masks. We DOLLY down a side street, now looking at the bank’s re wall. We CONTINUE until we are looking at First Texas Ban parking lot. Which is full. INT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- POST, TEXAS -- CONT. We stare at Toby and Tanner who stand frozen. We see what they see -- Two dozen people staring at them. Frozen as well. No one moves. No one knows what to do. Then it all happen a blur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanner raises his pistol, pointing it frantically at everyone. All the people hit the deck. Toby is cemented to the plac where he stands. Tanner jumps the counter, pressing his gun hard to the fa of the teller.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Open the drawers! Every teller open their drawer and take three steps back. Tanner spots his brother not moving.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: Toby snaps to, and covers the customers who are sitting a laying on the bank floor. Tanner begins grabbing the money himself from the teller drawers.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All of ya’1ll on your fucking knees. NOW. All the tellers drop to their knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl, in her twenties, laying on the floor, discreetly sending a text on her phone. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: THEY R ROBBING THE BANK
dialogues.text: Tanner is frantically scraping money from the drawers, on after the other, when an old SECURITY GUARD comes around corner, his pistol raised. He cocks the hammer -- Tanner spins and fires round after round into him. He fal back as everyone screams. Another man stands and pulls a pistol from his boot, fire Toby and misses. Toby turns and fires while he ducks. They aren’t thirty f from each other, but the twisting and ducking is sending bullets into the wall, the ceiling, everywhere but their intended target.  88. Tanner takes aim and places a round in the side of the ma head, dropping him to a heap on the floor, like a jacket falling from a coat rack. Tanner leaps over counter.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go! EXT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- POST, TEXAS -- CONT. Toby and Tanner push through the doors and are met by a h of gunfire. The windows behind them shatter as they fire back and duc behind the Grand Am, which is taking a beating.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: IT AIN'T. IT’S THE WHOLE FUCKING TOWN SHOOTIN’ AT US! Sure enough, across the road, hidden behind pickups, are locals with deer rifles, shotguns, whatever was in the gu rack when they heard shooting inside the bank. Tanner unl the passenger door, lays against the seat, and sticks the in the ignition. Cranks it to life. Folds the seat forwar

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get in. Toby dives in as the windows of the Pontiac shatter. Tann lays on the passenger seat, slams the car in reverse and his hand to press the gas pedal to the floor, his feet st hanging out the open door. The car races backwards as gunfire pulverizes the vehicle When the Pontiac is at a somewhat safer distance, we see disappear, the passenger door close, and the Grand Am is angrily around and slammed into drive, hauling ass down t street. Locals climb in their trucks to give chase. INT. GRAND AM -- CONT. Toby is panicking. Can't catch his breath. He’s hyperventilating. Tanner is as calm as he was at the poke table.  89.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Man, those concealed carry permits sure complicate a bank robbery, don’t they?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do??

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hey. We ain’t out of this, and I need you focused. Believe me when I say: this is where the rubber meets the road, little brother.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: How are we gonna get away from this? You killed two people. At least.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: And let me tell you something, we ain't through with that yet. You want to be anything but a black mark on your sons then I need you mountain lion mean, you understand me? Tanner looks in the rearview mirror and sees a half dozen pick ups and sedans coming up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on. Tanner slams on the brakes. The Grand Am’s tires smoke an scream as the car comes to a stop in the middle of the ro EXT. GRAND AM -- HWY 308 -- CONT. Tanner walks to the trunk, unlocks it, takes out the AR 1 and walks down the center of the highway toward the oncom vehicles. He raises the rifle to his shoulder and sprays the vehicl with thirty bullets in less than a second. All the vehicles slam to a stop as bullets pound into the windshields, their hoods, their grills. The vehicles are instantly in reverse and beating a hasty retreat as Tanner drops the empty magazine, slams home another, and peppers the fleeing vehicles again. He turns and gets back in the Pontiac.  The door closes and the Pontiac speeds away. EXT. HWY 308 -- DAY. The Pontiac pulls along side the Blazer. Toby opens and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Needless to say, don’t take the highway back through Post. Head south. South, then west, got it?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: We're done. Tanner looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: No we're not. Get to the Casino and change the money. Head north through New Mexico to the interstate. You take 287 back to Childress. Like we planned. Like you planned. This was your plan, and it’s worked every step of the way. Trust it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Where are you headed? Tanner just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be stupid. You get the fuck out of here too. 90. the door Toby heads to the Blazer, unlocks the door, crams the mon under the seat, takes off his baggy jeans and baggy jacke revealing wranglers and a sweat drenched t shirt.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hand those to me. He hands the baggy clothes to his brother. Tanner tosses in the back seat. Toby climbs in the Blazer.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Call me when you make it back to the ranch.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hey ... I love you ... I mean that, Toby.  91. Toby stares at his brother, shocked by the words.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I love you too. Tanner winks and drives away. INT. GRAND AM -- DAY. Tanner smokes a cigarette, A soulless country-rock song blaring. he shuts the radio off.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Can’t nobody write a country song worth a shit no more. He begins singing one himself -- a VERY OLD TEX RITTER SO

dialogues.speaker: AS I WALKED OUT ONE BRIGHT SUNNY
dialogues.text: MORNIN’ I SPIED A YOUNG COWBOY A

dialogues.speaker: LOPIN' ALONG, HIS HAPPY SHELL BACK,
dialogues.text: HIS SPURS A WAS A JINGLIN’, AND AS HE COME NEAR ME HE WAS SINGIN’ THIS SONG ... In the distance, three TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY vehicles, lights flashing, are moving toward him. Far to the left, a dirt road that winds up a shrub oak covered hill to a large, lone, oak tree that lords over t canyons and arroyos.

dialogues.speaker: YIPPEE HIYIYO, GET A LONG YOU
dialogues.text: LITTLE DOGGIES, IT’S YOUR

dialogues.speaker: NEW HOME ...
dialogues.text: As the cruisers approach, so does the dirt road. Tanner y the wheel, cutting in front of the cruisers, busting thro a barbed wire fence and spewing a rooster tail of dust as drives up the hill. The police cruisers give chase. In the distance, two more coming, headed by Marcus’s unmarked Crown Victoria. Tanner reaches the top of the hill, turns the car to face cruisers who are beginning to wind up the dirt road to hi  92. He pops the trunk, pulls out a satchel of rifle magazines his deer rifle, and a five gallon gas tank. He unscrews the top, crams the ski mask in the opening, a light it on fire. He places it in the passenger seat of the Pontiac and put the car in gear. The Pontiac begins moving toward the cruisers headed up t road, it picks up speed, on a certain collision course wi them. The cruisers stop, and begin backing down the hill. The Pontiac is catching up, and it is now that Tanner ope fire. He pounds the cruisers with gunfire. The Pontiac is ten f from them when the gas can explodes. The red fireball of metal slams into the retreating vehicles, knocking two of them into the arroyo that runs alongside the road. Tanner nods at his achievement, grabs his rifles, and crouches down, disappearing into the brush. Marcus's vehicle pulls up with the two cruisers. They get and take in the chaos playing out above them.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: My word. We need a S.W.A.T. unit up here and a chopper to pen this boy down. PARKER dials his cell. Marcus looks up the hill. His eyes are alive. At last: a fight. Troopers are running, zigzagging down the hill, motioning with their hands for everyone to get down. Over the burni vehicles one trooper yells.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER
dialogues.text: He’s got a rifle! Get down! We hear the crack of Tanner’s deer rifle in the distance. Marcus ducks behind a cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: This old boy’s out of his mind. Why don’t you slip up this canyon and tomahawk that son of a bitch.  93. Marcus turns back to PARKER, who is laid out on the pavem a bullet hole under his left eye. Marcus moves quickly to him, pulling him behind their vehicle. When he does he sees that the entire back of PARKER’s hea gone. He lets go of his arm and sits there, looking over friend, all the excitement of the chase now gone. Marcus hears trucks approaching, he turns and sees: Townspeople approaching. Marcus runs toward the oncoming vehicles, when they slow to a stop he hides behind the passenger side of the truck in front.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Back these trucks up behind that hill, he’s got a rifle up there.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: We know it, those bastards shot up half the town. Marcus takes in the irate cowboy and the deer rifle besid him. The man puts his truck in reverse, Marcus walking be the truck as he backs up.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: How well do you know the land around here?

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: Like the back of my hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He’s hid up under an old oak in the brush on that hill. Can I get around behind him?

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: Give me half an hour, and I'1l have that bastard field dressed on the hood of my truck.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Can’t let you do it. Get me there.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be a five hundred yard shot if he’s where you say. Marcus opens the passenger door, with determination in hi old face.  94.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Get me there. I’1l do the rest. Marcus climbs in and the truck drives off as Troopers run motioning the other vehicles to go back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanner lights a cigarette and watches the madness through scope of his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: The whole town come out for the show. What do you think of that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby drives as police cruiser after cruiser whips by in t opposite direction. Toby comes around a bend in the road and sees: FOUR SHERI DEPUTY VEHICLES blocking the road.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Shit. He slows and stops at the road block. A deputy approaches Toby’s window.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Where you headed?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Riudoso.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: ... Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Hamlin.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Taking the scenic route, huh.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Taking the only way I can. They got the road closed through Post. Hell, everywhere you turn the road’s closed. The deputy looks through the back window.  95.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY 2
dialogues.text: Got yer license on you?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY 2
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Toby hands it over and the deputy calls it in. Toby sits what seems like an eternity, trying to act bored or innoc or anything but what he is. The deputy walks back to the Blazer and hands him the license. DEPUTY 2 (CONT’D) Have a good day.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yep. You too. Toby puts it in drive and pulls past them. EXT. OAK TREE -- DAY. Tanner looks through his scope, with just the odd cowboy peering out from behind vehicles. Tanner looks bored.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: This ain’t much of a gun fight. Tanner considers pulling the trigger when one Trooper rac through the open from one vehicle to another.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gonna have to come after me at some point. In the distance he sees more police vehicles approaching what looks to be a S.W.A.T. van.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now we're talking. Tanner reaches for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I got time for one more. He places a cigarette in his mouth. Flicks his lighter. EXT. RIDGE LINE -- CONT.  96. We watch the lone tree THROUGH A RIFLE SCOPE and hear the labored breathing of a man far too old to crest hills lik the one he just climbed.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're pretty winded, you oughta let me take the shot. Hell, it’s my gun.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. We see them now, on the edge of a ridge almost half a mil from the tree. Marcus lays on his belly looking through the rifle scope, local beside him, looking through binoculars. MARCUS (CONT’D) He’s mine.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: I don’t see him yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Me neither. He’ll show himself soon enough. They sit, watching. A small plume of cigarette smoke rise near a bush. They both hone in on it.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got him.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: Me too. We look through the scope. We see the back of Tanner’s he

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got you ... (To the local) How low is this rifle gonna shoot at this distance?

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's dead on at three hundred. Hold ten inches above him and you'll split his skull. The scope’s cross hairs move above Tanner’s head ...

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look at you. Sitting right on the devil’s doorstep.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanner draws on his smoke, relishing it. Looking down on scampering police below him.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Won't be long now. Tanner nods with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lord of the plains. He takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s me. He exhales. A strange feeling comes over him. He senses something ... WE LOOK THROUGH THE SCOPE. We see Tanner turn his face toward us -- cross hairs just above his head -- looking right into the lens. The trigger is pulled. We hear the rifle roar. See the mu flash through the scope. Tanner's face drops to the dirt. Lifeless. INT. INDIAN CASINO -- RIUDOSA, NEW MEXICO -- NIGHT. Toby stands at the check in counter, exhausted. The clerk pecks in a computer.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Just one of you?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: How many nights ... Sir?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, what?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: How many nights?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: One.  98. INT. TOBY’S ROOM -- INDIAN CASINO -- RIUDOSA -- NIGHT. Toby stares at the ceiling, chip trays stacked full on th night stand. He looks at his cell phone. Nothing. He’s been resisting this. Once he knows, there’s no more hope. But he must know. Can’t put it off any longer. He t on the TV. A TV reporter stands in the city square of Post, a flurry activity behind her.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: ... When the townspeople of Post confronted the robbers, a shoot out reminiscent of the old west broke out right here, in the city square. The locals chased the robbers out of town, but not before three of their own were killed inside the bank and on these city streets. And like a story from a dime store novel, both members of the Texas Highway Patrol and locals chased the robbers to a hillside twenty miles east of town where the gunfight continued. Three highway patrolmen were injured, two critically, and one Texas Ranger was killed before Ranger Marcus Hamilton killed one of the gunman with a rifle he borrowed from a resident of this rugged little town.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: What information do we have on the bank robber that was killed?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: His name is Tanner Joseph Hanson, from Hamlin, Texas. He was convicted of an armed robbery back in 1997, and served twelve years of an eighteen year sentence.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Any word on his accomplice?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: No word yet. Officials speculate he is hiding somewhere in the canyons that surround this area. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They will continue the search through the night and are warning residents that he is armed and extremely dangerous. But as of yet, nothing is known about the accomplice and officials are hoping that someone will come forward and give them information that will lead to identifying who the other part of this duo that has caused so much havoc over the past few days.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Thank you, Kate. Wow. What a shocking story coming out of West Texas. In other news -- Toby shuts it off. Returns to staring at the ceiling, expecting it to fall on top of him. Tears build in his ey and run back to the mattress below him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, showered and decently dressed, sits across from the LOAN OFFICER who looks at the two checks from the casinos Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: (Dry as a bone) Lucky guy.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Mmhmm.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Just in the nick of time too... What are the odds.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Not great. He punches some numbers on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: This satisfies both the reverse mortgage loan and the back taxes that we paid on your mother’s behalf. We do that as a courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m sure.  100. Toby hands Billy’s business card to the Loan officer.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can fax the release of Lien to this number.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: (Looking over the card) An attorney.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. The loan officer nods.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: You’re aware that you can sell mineral rights separate from the surface rights of a property.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That a fact.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yeah. The odds there are actually minerals to extract are, well, it’s highly unlikely, but I can check and see what value the rights have and --

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Long odds are working pretty good so far. The release of lien, that’s all I want.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: I’ll get that faxed over to your attorney by the end of the week. The loan officer smiles. Toby doesn’t. Beat. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It is the end of the week. I want to watch you do it.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: It take a little time to prepare.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I got all day.  101.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Very well. Let me get it printed up. The loan officer hits a button and the printer spits out document. LOAN OFFICER (CONT’D) If I can just get you to sign here. Toby looks over the paper, reading every word. LOAN OFFICER (CONT’D) It’s all pretty standard -- Toby’s eyes burn into him. He sits back. Toby reads it li for line.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Didn't take that long, now, did it? Says here you'll mail the deed within seven days.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: That's right, that goes to your attorney as well, correct?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Toby signs the paper and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fax it. The loan officer places it in the fax, enters the number the card. The fax chirps and whines and pulls the paper through.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: That’s it. The loan officer stands. Offers his hand. LOAN OFFICER (CONT’D) Pleasure doing business with you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yes. Wasn’t it? Toby turns to leave, then stops. Turns back. An evil glea his eye.  102.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me ask you a question. Do y’all manage trusts? EXT. MARCUS HAMILTON’S HOUSE -- ABILENE, TEXAS -— DAY. It’s a month or so later. Marcus sits on his porch. Looks over his yard to the street. There’s traffic, there’s peo walking along the sidewalk. If anyone’s wondering where all the people from the littl towns went ... They all came here. A neighbor walks by pushing a stroller. She waves at Marc

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Thought the summer would never end.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Was a hot one.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Don’t know what we did to deserve it, but I'd say we’ve paid our penance.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll see. Not sure if the Good Lord's done with us yet. She wanders on down the street. A car horn honks. A dog barks. A siren in the distance. T is no peace in this place. Marcus finds solace in the newspaper. Flips to the sports page.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're breaking in that rocking chair, I see. Marcus looks up, though he doesn’t want to. Finds BARNEY CUMBERLAND, nearing 80, and happily settled into a life o purpose.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Going over to the Legion tonight, there’s supper and a decent card game. Wanna come along?  103. That sounds like hell.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I ain’t a veteran.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You'll come as my guest.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I appreciate it Barney, but I ain’t much of a card player. Barney laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You will be. Barney heads back toward his house.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Looking back) What else you gonna do? Marcus tries to focus on the paper, but the truth of Barn statement lingers. It’s too much. He tosses the paper dow and heads in the house. INT. MARCUS’S HOUSE -- LIVING ROOM -- CONT. He looks around -- thirty year old furniture in like new condition. Can’t decide where to go. Decides on his recli goes to it and sits. He reclines it back. Clicks on the TV. ESPN. The dull hum football rises from it. He closes his eyes and leans back It’s not working. He can’t do this one more minute... INT. TEXAS RANGER OFFICE -- ABILENE, TX -- DAY. Marcus walks in, past a secretary.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Hello, Margaret. A RANGER walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: That didn’t take long.  104.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Oh, just ... You know.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Not yet, but I will. Want some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Sure. Think I could take a peak at Tanner Hanson's file?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: How come? Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Nothing better to do.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: It’s in my office. They walk toward an office just off the main foyer. The Ranger hands Marcus the file as they both sit down. Marcu flips through it.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got Tanner's juvenile record unsealed. What a piece of work that boy was. Marcus reads it over.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Killed his father in a hunting accident?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: I’d love to know what he was hunting in the barn. In April. Marcus continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: His brother checked out?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: I don’t know about that, but there’s nothing that ties him to the robberies.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What about that little waitress in Vernon?  105.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: We showed her a picture, said she never seen him ... Pretty upset you took her tips as evidence.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That fat girl sure was sassy. Marcus holds up Tanner’s file photo and a blown up pictur Toby’s DMV photo --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You show these to that old timer?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Yep. We showed him Toby’s DMV photo and he said it didn’t look like the fella from the diner.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Old timer said they looked like brothers.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Well, he’s ninety years old, he didn’t recognize Tanner’s photo either. Marcus sips his coffee as he continues through the file. Holds up a REQUEST FOR WARRANT form.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I asked for a warrant on his bank accounts and the ranch, DA wouldn't do it. Toby’s got no record, never been arrested. Only court appearance he ever made was at his divorce. Marcus continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He owns this ranch?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Was his mamas. Now it’s in a trust for his kids, she died a month ago. Marcus raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Just before all this started ... And the ranch is in a trust.  106.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Mmhmm.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Ya’ll go out there?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. You wanna know the first thing I noticed? Two drilling crews from Chevron capping wells and putting in pump jacks... The engineer out there said they could pull 2000 barrels a month off that place. Know how rich that’1l make those kids?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Then why was Tanner running around robbing banks, if they’re so flush?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, whole thing stinks to me. But you try convincing a judge to issue warrants on somebody set to clear fifty thousand a month for stealing forty thousand from the bank that manages the trust on the property. Marcus raises the other eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: First Texas manages the trust?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: They ain’t the executor, but they hold the money. Oh, it’s one rotten fish, but damned if I can figure it. And you can bet your ass First Texas ain’t pressing it over forty thousand dollars. Lord knows what they stand to make. The Ranger sees the wheels turning in Marcus’s head.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marcus, if you want to come up here and dig through files, ask questions, that’s fine. There's always coffee in the pot for you, but you can’t go out there, okay? Marcus stares at the DMV photo of Toby.  107.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marcus ... You’re retired.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: Okay. Off the Ranger, not quite believing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby looks at a depression dug under a barbed wire fence leads to a small garden that has been destroyed. Toby walks to an old pickup and grabs a lever action rifl from the gun rack. He racks a round. Climbs over the fenc and follows pig tracks that lead from his garden to the mesquite thicket just beyond. He follows. He walks a deer trail through the thicket, following the tracks. He slows, creeping along the trail. It bends to t right. He creeps along the trail, then notices something moving to his right, along the dirt road that leads to the house ducks. Looks, and starts creeping back toward the house. MARCUS WALKS THE ROAD UP TO THE HOUSE. He looks up at it. It’s halfway through a new paint job, paint cans and rollers rest beside the porch. Toby steps quietly from the mesquites, coming up behind Marcus. Marcus turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Painting the house I see ... Know who I am? Toby steps closer, the rifle cradled in his arms. Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m the man who killed your brother. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it. I also know you're retired. And you're trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You could shoot me now and be within your rights. And you totin’ a gun. How convenient.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I imagine you've got one too. Marcus smiles. Toby stands there, waiting patiently whatever Marcus came here to do. Or say. Marcus has the edge of the porch.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You mind if I sit? Toby almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Feel free. Toby walks to the porch sits in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want a beer? Marcus thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Sure. I ain’t on duty no more. 108. for a seat on Toby grabs two from a small cooler and tosses him one.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice out here with the breeze, now that it’s cooled down. Texas is hell till September comes, ain’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It can be. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: How’d you do it -- never mind, I’‘1l figure that in time ... Why’d you do it?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why Tanner did it. He robbed those banks cuz he liked it. He shot my partner three hundred yards away cuz he liked it. Made him feel good. And if I hadn’t blown his shit-for-brains out, there’d be a brand new truck parked out front and four wheelers and anything else he could think to buy. He’d spend it all just to have an excuse to steal some more. But not you... Painting this old house yourself. Driving that beat up truck. Nothing new I can see, ‘cept those pump jacks and each of ‘em paying you a week what you and your brother stole from all four banks combined. 109. Marcus sips from his beer. Toby shifts the muzzle of his rifle discreetly in Marcus’s direction.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help me understand that ... Help me understand why four people died so you could steal money it don’t seem you've spent. That it don’t seem you need. Toby looks at Marcus, and his grin that begs for a fight. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You got a family?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: My partner had a family. A big one. They don’t have no pump jacks in their back yard. They’re gonna have to stretch a pension among the six of em.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I didn’t kill your friend.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yes you did. By setting this thing in motion. You expect me to believe your dim-witted brother planned all this? We’ve seen how he operated on his own. No, this was smart. This was you.  110. Beat. Toby looks over at a pump jack, undulating up and d drawing money from the earth with every revolution.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I been poor my whole life. So were my parents, and their parents before ‘em ... Like a disease, passed from generation to generation. And that’s what it becomes, a sickness ... Infecting every person you know ... But not my boys. Not anymore. This is theirs now. Ain’t no advice you can give a child these days. No lessons. No love. Nothing that can guarantee they have a chance at life, but money. I hate that the world’s come to this, but it has. And I dare you to look me in the eye and tell me different ... I never killed anyone in my life, but if you want me to start with you, let's get on with it, old man. See if you can get that pistol from your boot before I blast you off this porch. They hold each other’s gaze, no surrender in either man’s eyes, but no anger either, just the grim acceptance that had to be this way. An older Ford Expedition bounces up the dirt road and sto in front of the house. Justin, Debbie, and RANDY, 11, ste out, book bags over the boys’ shoulders. Debbie spots the gun in Toby’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That pig was back in the garden. (To Marcus) Feral hogs are tearing up this place somethin’ fierce.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I’m an old friend of your husband. Debbie recognizes Marcus instantly, but this isn’t her fi rodeo with playing dumb.  111.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Ex husband.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m just here working on the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You don’t live here?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It’s not mine. It’s theirs. Marcus looks at the boys. Then at Debbie. Stoic expressio giving away nothing ... They all know. He can tell. Has t laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Things you do for your kids, huh? Marcus rises.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I'd best be going. Toby stands as well.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Me too. (To Debbie) I’11 be back over around nine tomorrow, try and finish the front. She nods. Toby looks at Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I’m renting a little house in town. If you wanna come by and finish our conversation ... You're welcome anytime. A dare ... A threat ... Marcus looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I‘1l do that. I haven’t figured this whole thing out yet ... But I will. Marcus looks over at the boys. Studies them.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You as smart as your daddy?  112.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: I never thought of daddy as all that sharp. Marcus laughs. Leans down to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Don ou underestimate him. 'ty d timate hi He looks back at Toby.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Soon, I hope. I’m ready to be done with this.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You’1l never be done with it. No matter what. That’s the price. It’s gonna haunt you, son. For the rest of your days. Marcus looks up to the sky, letting the autumn sun bathe face. MARCUS (CONT’D) But you won’t be alone. It’s gonna haunt me too.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: When you come by, maybe I'll give you peace. Marcus smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe I’1l give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I'd like that ... Till that day. Marcus looks at this sad, simple man, and smiles. Tips hi hat, turns and walks up the dirt road. The camera rises and looks down on them. The house’s gray faded shingles and Marcus’s silver hat standing out from red dirt that surrounds them. THE END.  113.
